subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Grameen Bank: Banking on the Poor
description: A quick win: understand Grameen Bank: Banking on the Poor.

hook.text: In Bangladesh, Muhammad Yunus lent $27 to 42 women. Every single one repaid. Banks had called it insane.

buildup.text: Yunus founded Grameen Bank in 1983 to lend to people traditional banks rejected as too risky.

discovery.text: Grameen's secret was group lending: five borrowers guarantee each other, replacing collateral with trust.

twist.text: The bank's repayment rate hit 99.6%â€”better than most commercial banks serving wealthy customers.

climax.text: Grameen disbursed over $30 billion and is owned by its borrowers. Yunus won the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize.

punchline.text: The poorest borrowers became the world's most reliable.

quiz.question: What was Grameen Bank's repayment rate despite lending to the poorest borrowers?
options: Around 50%, which was acceptable given the risk
99.6%, higher than most commercial banks serving wealthy clients
75%, which required government subsidies to cover losses
